poem:
Title: In Anticipation of Transient Delights

Easter whispers from its chocolate crypt.
Proffering moments of honeyed warmth,
Small joys of creation, in boxed innocence.
Ah, but the hatchling, not the hare,
Betrays the world's transient delights.
There in its sugared shell, the bitter truth,
That life is laughter in a candy nest,
Forgotten too soon amidst the January frost.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Notes on chocolate: it’s time to start looking forward to Easter It may seem too early to be talking about Easter things, but life has taught me the best things sell out early because they’ve generally been in store since January. My latest discovery – and it’s a very good one – is Waitrose’s Hot Honey Hatchlings, £6/3. They really missed a trick and should have made them in the shape of bunnies and called". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
